chapter.title: Styling Your Documents
chapter.p: For each supported output format, there exists a subfolder transform/<format> below the installation folder. Inside this folder, the XSL stylesheets with the transformation rules for this target format and a style definition file style.xml are stored.

To modify the style definitions for a given target format, create and edit a copy of the corresponding style.xml file. Then use the -s command line switch to point the document processor to the new style file. The format and contents of the style definition file differ depending on the output format.

section.title: Editing the CSS-Stylesheet
section.p: The central style definition for XHTML is an old-fashioned CSS stylesheet, wrapped inside an XML container. For users who have previous experience with CSS, most parts of the stylesheet should be straight-forward to figure out. The following subsections pointing out the elements of the stylesheet concerning the page layout.

subsection.title: Frontpage and Table of Contents
subsection.p: The document head, carrying for example the title, authors, date of publication, publisher and copyright details, is set inside a div section with the id #head,

marked with a red outline in figure . The header elements themselves are arranged in a table with style class head, marked by the blue outline in figure. Each element is contained in a separate cell with style class head-element, e.g. head-title. The subtitle is set in the same cell as the main title, but wrapped in an extra div with style class subtitle, so that it can be styled differently from the main title.

The table of contents (TOC) is contained inside a div with id #toc, marked with a red outline in figure . The TOC heading and list of headings are set in divs with style classes toc-heading and listof-heading, respectively. The individual entries in the TOC are divs with style classes toc-mainitem or toc-subitem, the empty elements in between sections have style class toc-spacer. The indentation of the TOC entries cannot be influenced through the CSS stylesheet.

subsection.title: Text Body and Margin
subsection.p: The page contents are wrapped inside a div with id #content, marked with a red outline in figure . The main canvas and margin are table cells of classes textbody and margin, in a table with style class content, marked with a blue outline.

subsection.title: Navigation Elements
subsection.p: The top navigation bar is set inside a div with id nav-top, which in turns contains a table with the same style class name. The table has a cell nav-top-title displaying the document title and a cell nav-top-buttons containing the navigations buttons.

Analogously, the bottom navigation bar consists of a div with id nav-bottom containing a table carrying the same style class name. This table is split into three cells nav-bottom-left, nav-bottom-center and nav-bottom-right. The text labels and links to previous, next and superordinate sections (see fig. ) are styled in separate spans with style classes nav-link-dir (label) and nav-link (text).

figure.caption: The navigation bar at the page bottom.

subsection.title: Glossary and Index
subsection.p: The heading at the top of the glossary page is a simple h1 element. The heading at the beginning of each glossary section is also an h1 with additional style class glsection. The alphabetic quick links at the top, which allow you to quickly jump to certain sections are contained inside a div with class gllinks. Active links are spans of class gllink, and inactive of class glnolink. The horizontal rule between sections has style class glseparator.

Analogously to the glossary, the heading atop an index is an h1, and the heading at the beginning of each section is an h1 with additional style class idxsection. The alphabetic quick links are set in a container with class idxlinks and are themselves spans of style classes idxlink and idxnolink. The entries are arranged in a table of class idxlisting whose cells are styled with class idxitem. Each text entry is wrapped inside a span of class idxitem, idxsubitem or idxsubsubitem; indentation is controlled through these elements.

section.title: Changing the Look of &latex;-based Output
section.p: In the style definition file for &latex; you will find a separate section for each of the main document classes, each of which contains a list of stylable elements for that document class. Some basic knowledge of &latex; will be required to be able to edit these.
